title: 113_hr1582
content: The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 prohibits the Environmental Protection Agency from finalizing energy-related rules estimated to cost over $1 billion if they will have significant adverse effects on the economy. Prior reports and determinations are required before finalizing such rules. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 requires the EPA to report to Congress before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion, including estimates of costs and benefits. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 mandates the EPA to provide Congress with a report before implementing any energy-related rule exceeding $1 billion, including details on costs and benefits, along with a certification on the data used for estimating benefits. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 requires the EPA to provide Congress with a report before implementing any energy-related rule exceeding $1 billion. The report must include estimates of costs and benefits, along with details on the potential increases in energy prices for consumers resulting from the rule. The estimates are available for public review on the Agency's website, except for confidential information protected by law. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 mandates the EPA to submit a report to Congress before implementing any energy-related rule exceeding $1 billion. The report must include cost and benefit estimates, as well as details on potential consumer energy price increases resulting from the rule. The Secretary of Energy, in consultation with relevant agencies, will conduct an independent analysis to determine the rule's impact on energy prices for consumers. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 requires the EPA to report to Congress before implementing any energy rule over $1 billion. The report must include cost estimates, details on potential consumer energy price increases, and an analysis of impacts on energy prices for consumers, including low-income households, small businesses, and manufacturers. The rule's effects on fuel diversity, electric reliability, energy supply, distribution, and use must also be considered. The Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2013 requires the EPA to report to Congress before implementing any energy rule over $1 billion, including cost estimates, potential consumer energy price increases, and impacts on energy prices for consumers. The rule's effects on fuel diversity, electric reliability, energy supply, distribution, and use must also be considered. If the Secretary of Energy determines adverse effects on the economy, consultations with relevant agencies will be conducted to assess the impact. The Administration must determine if a rule will have significant adverse effects on the economy, considering costs, benefits, and impacts on economic indicators. The Administration must assess the impact of a rule on the economy, including unemployment, wages, consumer prices, business, and manufacturing activity, and publish the results in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "direct costs" and "indirect costs" are defined according to the Environmental Protection Agency's guidelines. The term "energy-related rule that is estimated to cost more than $1 billion" refers to EPA rules regulating energy production, supply, distribution, or use, estimated by the Administrator. The term "rule" is defined in section 551 of title 5, United States Code, and refers to regulations estimated to cost more than $1 billion in direct and indirect costs. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law. The term "social cost of carbon" refers to the cost described in a technical support document. The Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis was updated in May 2013 by the Interagency Working Group on Social Cost of Carbon, United States Government. The House of Representatives passed a bill related to monetized damages from increased carbon dioxide emissions on August 1, 2013. Attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
